awd_titl_txt: HBCU: Excellence in Research: Analysis and Modeling of the Ocean Spray Effects on Tropical Cyclone Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
It is well-documented that hurricane track forecasts have improved substantially over the recent decades, while forecasts of hurricane intensity change have lagged.  Hurricane intensity is sensitive to a variety of factors, such as wind shear and the internal organization of the cyclone.  One of the main uncertainties in research on hurricane behavior is the role of ocean spray on the system.  Ocean spray affects the air-sea exchange of momentum, heat, and moisture.  Direct observations in these conditions are rare and very difficult, so most of the understanding about ocean spray is from calmer conditions or numerical models.  In this project, the PI plans to come at the problem from the perspective of fundamental physical conservation laws, progressively building a more elaborate mathematical model of sea spray.  The eventual societal impact of this work would be through improvements in numerical weather models, which would translate to better forecasts of hurricanes and their impacts.  The project would also represent the enhancement of research and education at a Historically Black College and University.

The PI plans to develop a mathematically rigorous and physically sound model of a marine atmospheric boundary layer laden with evaporating sea spray and perform numerical and asymptotic analyses of the model to create an efficient parameterization of a sea spray effect on tropical cyclone dynamics and structure.  The starting point will be a set of fundamental conservation laws which will be applied to systematically develop progressively more comprehensive models in such a way that the influence of newly added physical factors is clearly identifiable.  Under the first objective of developing the model, the PI plans the derivation of macro-scale, multi-fluid transport equations, formulation of the multi-phase turbulence model, and analysis of the droplet population dynamics.  The asymptotic and numerical analysis of the model would be conducted by performing regular asymptotic expansions, singular asymptotic expansions, and numerical analysis of the model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intensity of hurricanes is largely defined by the exchange of sensible and latent heat and momentum between the air and sea within its spray-laden marine atmospheric boundary layer (MABL). This is because a hurricane gains its energy mainly via a flux of heat transferred from the ocean and loses it through momentum transport back to the ocean. Numerous studies have indicated that sea spray plays an important role in this exchange. Nevertheless, the complete understanding and accurate quantification of the sea spray effect are still lacking. Findings from this project published in several influential papers lay the foundation for comprehensive understanding of the impact of spray on hurricane dynamics and improving the accuracy of their forecast.

We have developed an advanced mathematical model of a marine MABL laden with evaporating sea spray. Due to the complexity of the studied phenomena, we have evolved the model gradually by systematically incorporating additional physical factors. Specifically, we comprehensively described the thermodynamic and mechanical effects of spray on the airflow. The governing equations are derived from basic physical principles of conservation of momentum, mass, and thermal energy in multiphase flows. The developed model consistently quantifies three distinct mechanisms through which the spray mechanically influences the boundary layer dynamics: 1) spray inertia; 2) turbulence attenuation caused by the air-droplet friction; and 3) turbulence damping via its energy loss due to the vertical transport of spray against gravity by turbulent eddies. The first mechanism decelerates the airflow and the last two increase its speed with an overall effect sensitively depending on a multitude of physical governing parameters. Using the developed model, we extensively examined the influence of sea spray on the vertical fluxes of sensible and latent heat as well as momentum in the MABL for different droplet sizes, vertical distributions of air temperature, humidity, and turbulent intensity. The key findings are summarized below.

1. The turbulence suppression by spray overpowers its inertia several meters above wave crests, resulting in a noticeable wind acceleration and the corresponding reduction of the air-sea drag coefficient even if the spray concentration is relatively low.

2. Large droplets significantly increase both latent and total heat fluxes by producing steep vertical gradients of moisture and air temperature within a MABL. However, small droplets, virtually do not alter the total heat flux and only redistribute the energy between its sensible and latent components.

3. Evaporating spray affects the turbulence intensity and that of the vertical turbulent transport through various mechanical rather than thermodynamic attenuation mechanisms by altering the vertical air temperature and moisture profiles.

4. The vertical profiles of heat fluxes exhibit a near-similar behavior across a broad spectrum of defining parameters indicating that they can be approximately scaled to a reference heat profile for various vertical distributions of temperature, humidity, and turbulence intensity.

5. The thermodynamic and mechanical effects are coupled but this coupling is not symmetric: the turbulence reduction due to mechanical influence of spray strongly affects heat fluxes while alterations of the thermodynamic properties of a MABL have only a minor effect on turbulence intensity and wind speed.

For broader impact, this project has helped NCAT, a doctoral research-intensive HBCU, to build research and educational capacity in the areas of applied mathematics and scientific computing with applications to atmospheric fluid dynamics and multiphase turbulent flows. New courses in Atmospheric Fluid Dynamics and Atmospheric Turbulence have been developed and offered for the first time at North Carolina A&T State University (NCAT) to Applied Science and Technology Ph.D. students. These courses enable doctoral students to gain and strengthen their knowledge of atmospheric turbulence fundamentals and boundary layer dynamics contributing to students’ success with their doctoral research tasks. The project has also offered research training in mathematical and numerical modeling of multiphase turbulent atmospheric flows, applied mathematics, and computational science to one PhD student and two research associates.
